head.title: Limiting Lawsuits Rewards New York's Lapses

hedline.hl1: Limiting Lawsuits Rewards New York's Lapses

block.p: New York City is again seeking tort reform because it paid a record amount in 1995 for personal injury claims (news article, Dec. 28). This is an oft-repeated cry by the city and a case of the wrongdoer turning the tables against the wronged.

New York City is again seeking tort reform because it paid a record amount in 1995 for personal injury claims (news article, Dec. 28). This is an oft-repeated cry by the city and a case of the wrongdoer turning the tables against the wronged.

If the city were granted special protections against personal injury suits, the city would not be more careful and cause fewer injuries from broken sidewalks, police misconduct and poorly run hospitals. In fact, negligence and other wrongdoing would flourish unchecked because there would be a limited financial penalty against the city.
The city seeks to turn the tables against the injured victim in limiting that person's recovery for injuries although there are no limits as to the harm the city can perpetrate.

I applaud the Comptroller's plan to make each city agency responsible for its claims payments so that there is a measure of accountability. However, reducing payments through restricting the public's right to hold the city responsible in court should not be used to balance the budget.
If you want New York City to pay fewer settlements, then fix the sidewalks!
MARK E. SEITELMAN New York, Dec. 28, 1995 The writer is a lawyer.
